data.title: Eurovision musicology blog 2024
data.meta_description: Joe Bennett's annual Eurovision musicology commentary, with song & lyric analysis, and pre-voting predictions.
data.text:
Winners vs predictions

[the next day]

Phew! What an intense evening. One media outlet described it as â€œbeset by chaosâ€, and there was certainly a lot of drama â€“ from the last minute disqualification of the Netherlands entry to the various geo-political gestures and commentaries. My team and I did pretty well this year â€“ we predicted the top 2 (juxtaposed) and all 7 of my Top 10 nods were correct.

The blogging highlight for me was the discovery/invention of the EPC (Eurovision Population Coefficient) statistic â€“ see Luxembourg commentary below. Itâ€™s a way of measuring Eurovision winning history per head of population (Luxembourg, Ireland, and Estonia lead the pack). I hope this can become a thing at Eurovision from now on.

Original live* analysis and predictions below

Welcome to the Eurovision live musicology blog, now in its 13th year. For context, hereâ€™s the 2020 10-year corpus research summary, and the archive of all the posts in reverse order.

Tonight Iâ€™m pleased to welcome guest blogger and UK-based copyright analyst Maddy Plummer, who has provided additional research, as well as her own reviews for UK, Austria, Armenia, Spain, Cyprus and Portugal. Additional research was provided by the estimable Rafi Waters, who has done a terrific job working on the BPMs and chord loops. I should also add that he is graduating from Berklee today â€“ congratulations Rafi!

As always, Iâ€™ve provided commentary on each song, so you can follow along with the show, or (later) watch the embedded videos. And Iâ€™m going to try to predict the winner, before voting begins, then leave the prediction up here for posterity when the votes are in.

Americans â€“ the show goes out live at 3pm Eastern time on Saturday May 11, 2024. You can watch live with a free Peacock TV account.

Europeans â€“ you know the drill.

* I have actually pre-blogged everything based on the Spotify Eurovision finalists playlist, but the blog is published on the day of the final (before the voting begins) so should be read live alongside the show as it is broadcast.

Predictions 2024

Here are my predictions for 2024, made at 12.50 US Eastern time (18.50 Swedish time), before the show starts in MalmÃ¶:

Croatia

Switzerland

Israel

France, Ukraine, Ireland, and Italy to place in the top 10.

(Iâ€™ll be watching the show as it goes out, so may change these predictions as I see the performances â€“ but will be sure to lock it all down before voting begins!)

Letâ€™s do this!

01 ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡ª â€¢ Sweden â€¢ Unforgettable

Marcus & Martinus â€¢ 117 â€¢ C#m

Songwriters: Jimmy â€œJokerâ€ ThÃ¶rnfeldt, Joy Deb, Linnea Deb, Marcus Gunnarsen, Martinus Gunnarsen

What a great way to open the show. Yes, I know the opener and closer are randomly selected, but the dice have fallen fortuitously tonight (more on dice-rolling when we get to Greece later on). This is the sort of thing weâ€™ve come to expect from the Swedes â€“ Electro-pop minor-key bangers, sung in English at around 120BPM with pounding analogue synths, super dry four-on-the-floor kick drum, and lots of those â€˜risersâ€™ â€“ the rocket-effect synth lifts that take you into each chorus. Similar songs include â€œEuphoriaâ€ by Loreen (2012), â€œHeroesâ€ by MÃ¥ns ZelmerlÃ¶w (2015), â€œDance You Offâ€ by Benjamin Ingrosso (2018), and of course last yearâ€™s winner â€œTattooâ€ by Loreen (2023). And whatâ€™s to hate? They do it so well. This is why my pretty good ESC batting average holds up â€“ I always believe in Sweden.

Marcus and Martinusâ€™s performance looks â€“ and sounds â€“ like the VR game Beat Saber. The arrangement is all rising ramps. The kick drum stays away until the second verse â€œchew you upâ€, then drops out after only 8 bars so the first pre-chorus has no drums at all. Then everything drips in during the first chorus over each title repeat: kick and bass, then 2x octave synth, short drums tacet for 2 beats, giving us space to feel the beat on the next prechorus. Itâ€™s as if a DJ took over the songwriting, and this technique â€“ of simply dropping instruments in and out â€“ creates a fantastic journey for the dance floor, if itâ€™s used with the right timing. I love the extra bar just before the title hook, manipulating the phrase length to keep the dancers interested (itâ€™s an old ABBA trick). For me, it feels like it never quite hits top gear. This is partly because the melody never goes beyond a limited range of a 5th â€“ highest note is G#4, lowest is C#4. And the chord loop is (understandably) the same throughout â€“ | C#m | C#m | A | F#m |.

So this is another one of â€œthose Swedish dance songsâ€ that Eurovision has loved so many times. Itâ€™s good, but not exceptional enough to stick in the memory after the laser lights have faded. Maybe that title is asking for too much.

02 ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ â€¢ Ukraine â€¢ Teresa & Maria

alyona alyona & J. Heil â€¢ 114 â€¢ G Aeolian

Songwriters: Aliona Savranenko, Anton Chilibi, Ivan Klymenko, Yana Shemaieva

In my 2020 Eurovision research we analysed 259 ESC songs 2010-2019 and categorised them according to various themes: Love, Unity, Self-Assertion, Partying, History, and songs about music/dancing. â€œTeresa & Mariaâ€ covers at least three of these, plus Catholicism, old-school seasonal metaphysics, anti-war sentiments, and life-is-short existentialism thrown in. The message seems to be â€œseize the dayâ€ and Jerry and alyona are selling it well with some joyful vocals and an in-yer-face rap breakdown section. Sonically, itâ€™s an updated Enigma approach; with hypnotic chanting vocals over a Euro-friendly chord loop | Gm F | Cm Eb | and a super basic four on the floor rock beat.

We know thereâ€™s a lot of love for the Ukranians right now, and I think this is as good as their winning â€œStefaniaâ€ from 2022 (similar approach in the chorus vocals). Itâ€™s good. But is it good enough to beat the Croatians?

03 ğŸ‡©ğŸ‡ª â€¢ Germany â€¢ Always on the Run

Isaak â€¢ 110 â€¢ Bb minor

Songwriters: Greg Taro / Isaak Guderian / Kevin Lehr / Leo Jupiter

A song of struggling with demons, and trying to deal with the pressures of everyday life. But if Isaakâ€™s smiley and charismatic performance is any indicator, he seems pretty happy with his lot. The delivery is very Lewis Capaldi, and I suspect his selection at Germanyâ€™s â€œDas deutsche Finaleâ€ had something to do with his great vocal tone. Clearly the writing team wants to exploit that, so we hear parts of Always On The Run in two different octaves, with the bridge â€œRun from the silence, screaminâ€™ for guidanceâ€ beginning in his baritone range, bottoming out at c#3. When it goes up the octave 4 bars later he has to hit A#4 â€“ quite a spread for (what sounds to me like) an intuitive, non-trained singer. Given that my first listens were based on the German national final, he wasnâ€™t quite managing the lower pitches accurately when singing live (and remember the ESC rules require lead vocals to be fully live). So Iâ€™m listening carefully to see if he nails it.

Harmonically, weâ€™re in the ESC-friendly Aeolian mode (natural minor scale). Everything is a 4 or 8-bar loop harmonically; the verses are | Bbm | Bbm | Db | Db | Ebm | Ebm | Bbm | Bbm | (oooh distorted plectrum electric bass â€“ nice!) and the chorus paces up the harmonic rhythm | Gb | Ebm | Bbm | Ab | (x2). The â€œRun from the silenceâ€ bridge uses the chorus chords in a different order | Gb | Ebm | Bbm | Ab | (x4). If the singing is on the money tonight, Iâ€™d place this on in the upper-middle of the pack.

04 ğŸ‡±ğŸ‡º Luxembourg â€¢ Fighter

Tali â€¢ 95 â€¢ F#m

Songwriters: Manon Romiti / Silvio Lisbonne / Ana Zimmer / Dardust

Luxemburg is back! They have been absent from the contest since 1993. Before that, they won a remarkable 5 times (1961, 1965, 1972, 1973, 1983) â€“ not bad for a country of less than a million people.

This information has inspired me to create a new statistics game. If we know the population of a European country, the number of times theyâ€™ve entered Eurovision, and the number of times theyâ€™ve won, we can create a win-rate â€˜scoreâ€™, prorated for the size of the country. Iâ€™m going to call it the â€œEurovision Population Coefficientâ€ (EPC). It measures the proportional level of Eurovision-win talent in each citizen. Here is the formula.

If we multiply this number by 1 million this provides a wins-per-million (WPM) stat in the population. Here are the EPC scores across the whole history of the Contest 1956-2023, for the top 20 of tonightâ€™s finalists. As expected, Luxembourg has the highest EPC by a huge margin. To beat them, Ireland is going to have to really ramp up the wins in future. Or join the Schengen area and start a mass emigration scheme to Luxembourgâ€¦

Anyway, back to the song. Luxembourg are celebrating their return with this fun upper-middle-ranking entry. More of the almost-cumbia minor-key groove material that weâ€™ve seen so much of in the last 10 years or so (and more since Despacito). For me, there are two really cool bits â€“ the â€œhah!â€ in the middle of each chorus and the â€œJâ€™avoue, jâ€™avoue, je sais pas, je veux tout et rien Ã  la foisâ€ bizarre but arresting harmonic minor run at the end â€“ where did that come from? The indomitable spirit of the lyric stands out â€“ sort of Firework meets Youâ€™ve Got a Friend. Not a lot of win potential, but itâ€™s good to have them back.

05 ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡± â€¢ Israel â€¢ Hurricane

Eden Golan â€¢ 87 â€¢ Em

[Please note: The ESC is a non-political event, and this blog â€“ and my commentary â€“ is exclusively about music and songwriting.]

This is a great vocal, and although itâ€™s right on the edge of predictable diatonic-piano-ballad-by-numbers, I think the voters are going to go for it. The chorus opening â€œpromise me youâ€™ll hold me againâ€ starts off on a chord of Am, with Eden leaning on the same/equivalent note as starts Franceâ€™s Mon Amour. There are a couple of moments where the safeness recedes â€“ I like the cross-beat rhymes of the pre chorus â€œHours and hours, empowers / Life is no game but itâ€™s oursâ€. The production gives us some great ear candy â€“ the 8th-note echoed water droplets after chorus 1 are very cool â€“ and Eden does a great job with the up-the-octave theme after the final chorus. The chorus chord loop feels familiar but isnâ€™t â€“ itâ€™s actually quite tough to find a lot of songs with (in G major) | Am | Em | G | D | (ii-vi-I-V). Quite an achievement to find a relatively unusual combination of the worldâ€™s favourite chords!

As disclaimerâ€™d above, I make no comment on the politics, but I think this one could do really well.

06 ğŸ‡±ğŸ‡¹ Lithuania â€¢ Luktelk

Silvester Belt â€¢ 140 â€¢ E minor

Songwriters: Silvestras BeltÄ— (Silvester Belt) , DÅ¾esika Å yvokaitÄ— (Jessica Shy) & Elena JurgaitytÄ— (Elayork)

Starts boldly, with the filtered organ part from The Whoâ€™s Wonâ€™t Get Fooled Again. Then the beat drops, and itâ€™s pretty sparse â€“ techno drum machine and synth bass all the way. This is one of many songs tonight that deals with themes of emergence, opportunity, breaking the routine, and finding fulfilment, perhaps through love. â€˜Luktelkâ€™ means â€˜waitâ€™, and it seems to be an exhortation to understanding, as the protagonist shares his responsibility to dance & party, even though he initially doesnâ€™t feel it. I admire the bleak-at-first glance couplet â€œStovime tyloje grojanÄio radijo / Nebenoriu Å¡okt, nebenoriu Å¡oktâ€ (â€œWeâ€™re standing in the silence of the radio playing / I donâ€™t wanna dance, but I have to dance.â€). Being stuck indoors throughout 2020 sure did get some songwriters dreaming of a better tomorrow.

The musical backbone of the verses and choruses is a 2-chord 4-bar pattern | Em | Em | Bm | Bm |, apart from a short post-chorus section with no drums that briefly takes us to G major, and also the bridge, which is a descending | Em | D | C | A |. I particularly liked that A major chord at the end of the first repeat, bringing just 4 beats of dorian mode to the song, which is enough of a surprise for the 2-chord loop to drive a sense of chorus-y familiarity when it returns.

Silvester is a deeply engaging performer â€“ heâ€™s dancing throughout and enjoying the moment, all the while waving his arms as if heâ€™s spinning invisible DJ decks. This is one for the after-show party.
